algorithm_technique: Concatenate n, 2*n, 3*n, then use a bitmask to track seen digits 1-9.
Concatenate n, 2*n, 3*n into a string and check length and unique characters.
problem_summary_simple: Is a 3-digit number fascinating if concatenating it with 2*n and 3*n results in digits 1-9 exactly once?
problem_summary_technical: Concatenates n, 2*n, 3*n and verifies the resulting string contains digits 1-9 exactly once, without zeros.
key_insights: The problem requires checking for the presence of digits 1-9 exactly once. A bitmask is an efficient way to track seen digits.
The constraint that the number must not contain any zeros is crucial.
The time complexity is dominated by converting numbers to strings or processing digits, which is logarithmic to the value of the numbers.
Concatenating the numbers into a single string simplifies the check for digit presence and uniqueness.
Checking the length of the concatenated string (must be 9) and the size of the set of its characters (must be 9) ensures all digits 1-9 are present exactly once.
The presence of '0' must be explicitly checked.
